name: Agriculture
shortdescription: Study general agricultural principles to solve practical problems.
description: Learn general principles and practice of agricultural research and production so you can help solve practical agricultural problems. Study basic animal, plant, and soil science; animal husbandry and plant cultivation; soil conservation; and agricultural operations such as farming, ranching, and agricultural business.

name: Agricultural Business and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage and operate agricultural enterprises.
description: Study modern business and economic principles involved in the organization, operation, and management of agricultural enterprises.

name: Agribusiness/Agricultural Business Operations
shortdescription: Learn how to manage agricultural enterprises within larger corporations.
description: Manage agricultural businesses and agriculturally related operations within diversified corporations. Study agriculture, agricultural specialization, business management, accounting, finance, marketing, planning, human resources management, and other managerial responsibilities.

name: Agricultural Economics
shortdescription: Learn how to apply economic analysis to agriculture.
description: Apply economics to the analysis of resource allocation, productivity, investment, and trends in domestic and international agricultural sectors. Study economics and related subfields as well as applicable agricultural fields.

name: Farm/Farm and Ranch Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage all aspects of a farm or ranch, from finances to estate planning.
description: Manage farms, ranches, and similar enterprises. Study applicable agricultural specialization, business management, accounting, taxation, capitalization, purchasing, government programs and regulations, operational planning and budgeting, contracts and negotiation, and estate planning.

name: Agricultural/Farm Supplies Retailing and Wholesaling
shortdescription: Learn how to sell and market agricultural products.
description: Sell agricultural products and supplies, provide support services to agricultural enterprises, and purchase and market agricultural products. Study basic business management, marketing, retailing and wholesaling operations, and applicable principles of agriculture and agricultural operations.

name: Agricultural Business Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn how to efficiently run an agricultural business office.
description: Perform specialized support functions related to agricultural business offices and operations and operate agricultural office equipment, software, and information systems. Study basic agricultural business principles, office management, equipment operation, standard software, and database management.

name: Agricultural Mechanization
shortdescription: Learn how to sell, service and select agricultural technology and equipment.
description: Sell, select, and service agricultural or agribusiness technical equipment and facilities, including computers, specialized software, power units, machinery, equipment structures, and utilities. Study agricultural power systems, planning and selecting materials for the construction of support facilities, mechanical practices associated with irrigation and water conservation, erosion control, and agricultural data processing systems.

name: Agricultural Power Machinery Operation
shortdescription: Learn how to operate a variety of agricultural equipment.
description: Operate specialized farm, ranch, and agribusiness power equipment that is stationary, mobile, and/or hand-operated. Study the operation of specialized equipment like terrestrial and airborne crop-spraying equipment; tractors and hauling equipment; planting and harvesting equipment; cutting equipment; power sources and systems for silos, irrigation, pumping, and applications such as dairy, feeding and shearing operations; processing equipment; and applicable electrical, mechanical, and safety principles.

name: Agricultural Mechanics and Equipment/Machine Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn how to maintain and repair specialized agricultural equipment.
description: Maintain and repair specialized farm, ranch, and agribusiness power equipment and vehicles. Study principles of diesel, combustion, electrical, steam, hydraulic, and mechanical systems and their application to the maintenance of terrestrial and airborne crop-spraying equipment; tractors and hauling equipment; planting and harvesting equipment; cutting equipment; power sources and systems for silos; irrigation and pumping equipment; dairy, feeding, and shearing operations; and processing systems.

name: Agricultural Production Operations
shortdescription: Learn about producing plant and animal products.
description: Study general planning, economics, and use of facilities, natural resources, equipment, labor, and capital to produce plant and animal products. Prepare for work in farming, ranching, and agribusiness.

name: Irrigation Management Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn how to design, install and repair irrigation and drainage systems.
description: Work in the field of agricultural technology and irrigation. Study irrigation and drainage methodologies, pumping and delivery systems, system design and evaluation, and principles of installation and repair of irrigation systems.

name: Animal/Livestock Husbandry and Production
shortdescription: Learn how to select, breed and care for animals in agricultural production.
description: Select, breed, care for, process, and market livestock and small farm animals. Study basic animal science, animal nutrition, and animal health as applied to various species and breeds; design and operation of housing, feeding, and processing facilities; and related issues of safety, applicable regulations, logistics, and supply.

name: Aquaculture
shortdescription: Learn how to produce fresh and saltwater fish, shellfish and plants.
description: Select, culture, propagate, harvest, and market domesticated fish, shellfish, and marine plants, both freshwater and saltwater. Study basic principles of aquatic and marine biology; health and nutrition of aquatic and marine life; design and operation of fish farms, breeding facilities, culture beds, and related enterprises; and related issues of safety, applicable regulations, logistics, and supply.

name: Crop Production
shortdescription: Learn how to grow fruits, vegetables, grains and plants,
description: Cultivate grain, fiber, forage, oilseed, fruits and nuts, vegetables, and other domesticated plant products. Study basic principles of plant science, health, and nutrition as applied to particular species and breeds; soil preparation and irrigation; pest management; planting and harvesting operations; product marketing; and applicable issues of safety, regulation, logistics, and supply.

name: Dairy Husbandry and Production
shortdescription: Learn how to select and breed dairy animals to produce dairy products.
description: Manage the selection and care of dairy animals and associated dairy farm and processing facilities and operations. Study basic animal and dairy science; dairy animal nutrition and health; design and operation of dairy housing, feeding, and processing facilities and equipment; and related issues of safety, sanitation, shipping and handling, and applicable regulations.

name: Horse Husbandry/Equine Science and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to breed horses and manage stables.
description: Manage the selection, breeding, care, and maintenance of work, athletic, and show horses; and to manage horse farms, stables, tracks and related equipment and operations. Study principles of animal science, care, and health; stable and track management; design and operation of facilities and equipment; and related issues such as regulations, business management; and logistics.

name: Agroecology and Sustainable Agriculture
shortdescription: Learn how to solve agricultural and environmental problems in sustainable ways.
description: Learn about agricultural principles and practices that, over the long term, enhance environmental quality, make efficient use of nonrenewable resources, integrate natural biological cycles and controls, and are economically viable and socially responsible; and that may prepare individuals to apply this knowledge to the solution of agricultural and environmental problems. Study principles of agroecology, crop and soil sciences, entomology, horticulture, animal science, weed science and management, soil fertility and nutrient cycling, applied ecology, agricultural economics, and rangeland ecology and watershed management.

name: Viticulture and Enology
shortdescription: Learn how to produce and market grapes and wines.
description: Learn about applying scientific and agribusiness principles to the production of grapes, the making of wine, and the wine business. Includes instruction in grapes and wines of the world; grape production; winemaking technology; plant biology; chemistry; food science, safety, and packaging; soil science; pest management; and marketing and business management.

name: Apiculture
shortdescription: Learn how to promote and manage bee colonies to pollinate fruits and vegetables.
description: Improve the beekeeping industry, promote pollination of fruits and vegetables, and bee colony expansion and maintenance. Study apiary behavior, apiary equipment and supplies, beekeeping, bee pests and parasites, handling bees, hive set up and care, queen rearing, and seasonal management practices.

name: Agricultural and Food Products Processing
shortdescription: Learn how to process and store agricultural and food products.
description: Receive, inspect, store, process, and package agricultural products in the form of human food consumables, animal or plant food, or other industrial products. Study the nutrient and industrial properties of various agricultural products; logistics and storage procedures; chemical and mechanical processing operations; packaging; safety and health requirements; and related technical and business principles.

name: Dog/Pet/Animal Grooming
shortdescription: Learn how to groom and style pets, work and show animals.
description: Provide cosmetic services for household pets, show animals, work animals and animal athletes. Study skin, coat, and pelt grooming and styling; skin care; hoof, nail, and claw care; animal massage; minor first aid and veterinary referral; animal grooming products and applications; health and safety; and applicable regulations.

name: Animal Training
shortdescription: Learn how to train and exercise pets, sport, show and professional animals.
description: Teach and exercise animals for leisure, sport, show, and professional purposes. Study animal psychology, health, and safety; human-animal interaction; learning and behavior styles associated with different breeds and species; and the technical and pedagogical aspects of training animals for such specific functions as obedient household pets, performing show animals, animal athletes, care-giving (e.g., seeing-eye dogs), search and rescue, and police/security work.

name: Equestrian/Equine Studies
shortdescription: Learn how to care for, train and breed horses.
description: A program that focuses on the horse, horsemanship, and related subjects and prepares individuals to care for horses and horse equipment; ride and drive horses for leisure, sport, show, and professional purposes; and manage the training of horses and riders. Includes instruction in horse breeding, nutrition, health, and safety; history of the horse and horsemanship; horse development and training; riding and equestrian technique; stable, paddock, and track management; and equipment maintenance and repair.

name: Taxidermy/Taxidermist
shortdescription: Learn how to create life-like reproductions of animals for display.
description: Reproduce life-like three-dimensional representations of living animals for permanent display using elements of the deceased specimen(s) as well as artificial materials, and to manage taxidermy services and businesses. Study specimen grading and selection, caping and fleshing, preservation procedures, tanning, drying, measurements, form and armature construction, carpentry and woodworking, molding and casting, drawing, sculptural techniques, painting and finishing techniques, basic business operations, customer communications, and applicable laws and regulations.

name: Farrier Science
shortdescription: Learn how to shoe and care for horses' hooves
description: Become a specialist in equine hoof care (farriers). Includes instruction in equine science, equine health and first aid, general horseshoeing, corrective horseshoeing, gait analysis, and metal forging techniques using gas or coal.

name: Applied Horticulture/Horticulture Operations
shortdescription: Learn how to manage a business that grows plants and processes them.
description: Produce and process domesticated plants, shrubs, flowers, foliage, trees, groundcovers, and related plant materials; manage technical and business operations connected with horticultural services; and learn about the basic scientific principles needed to understand plants and their management and care.

name: Ornamental Horticulture
shortdescription: Learn how to breed, grow and use ornamental plants in a variety of settings.
description: Study domesticated plants and plant materials used for decorative and recreational applications. Learn how to breed, grow, and utilize ornamental plant varieties for commercial and aesthetic purposes. Study plant science subjects, the environmental design and artistic aspects of horticultural product usage, and managing horticultural operations.

name: Greenhouse Operations and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage, grow and store plants in a controlled indoor environment.
description: Produce, store, and deliver plant species in controlled indoor environments for wholesale, commercial, research, or other purposes. Study principles of plant science; climate, irrigation, and nutrition control equipment operation and maintenance; facilities management; inventory control; safety procedures; and personnel supervision.

name: Landscaping and Groundskeeping
shortdescription: Learn how to maintain indoor and outdoor plants in designed spaces.
description: A program that prepares individuals to manage and maintain indoor and/or outdoor ornamental and recreational plants and groundcovers and related conceptual designs established by landscape architects, interior designers, enterprise owners or managers, and individual clients. Includes instruction in applicable principles of horticulture, gardening, plant and soil irrigation and nutrition, turf maintenance, plant maintenance, equipment operation and maintenance, personnel supervision, and purchasing.

name: Plant Nursery Operations and Management
shortdescription: Learn how operate a plant nursery business.
description: Operate and manage outdoor plant farms, tree and shrub nurseries, and related facilities that develop domesticated plant products for propagation, harvesting, and transplantation. Study principles of plant science, farm and business management, nursery operations, equipment operation and maintenance, safety procedures, and personnel supervision.

name: Turf and Turfgrass Management
shortdescription: Learn how to grow and maintain turfgrass, and transport it for planting.
description: Learn about turfgrasses and related groundcover plants and how to develop ornamental or recreational grasses and related products; plant, transplant, and manage grassed areas; and to produce and store turf used for transplantation. Study plant sciences, genetics of grasses, turf science, use analysis, turf management, and related economics.

name: Floriculture/Floristry Operations and Management
shortdescription: Learn how operate a florist business.
description: Operate and manage commercial and contract florist enterprises, supply and delivery services, and flower catering services. Study principles of plant science; purchasing, storage, and delivery systems; floral design and arranging; and principles of business management.

name: Public Horticulture
shortdescription: Learn how to connect the value, science and beauty of plants to the public.
description: Study a combination of traditional horticulture and public education and outreach. Study botany, soil science, plant science, agricultural economics, leadership, and business.

name: Urban and Community Horticulture
shortdescription: Learn how to grow and manage crops in cities.
description: Learn principles and techniques for the production of horticultural crops in an urban environment. Study ecology, environmental sustainability, food production systems, and plant and soil sciences.

name: International Agriculture
shortdescription: Learn ways to solve global food problems.
description: Apply agricultural management and scientific principles to the problems of global food production and distribution, and to the study of the agricultural systems of other countries. Study agricultural economics; comparative agricultural systems; international agribusiness and law; third-world development studies and economic development; and global applications of climate, soil, water resources, ecological and environmental studies, and animal and plant sciences.

name: Agricultural and Extension Education Services
shortdescription: Learn how to help farmers and gardeners improve their yields and solve problems.
description: Provide referral, consulting, technical assistance, and educational services to gardeners, farmers, ranchers, agribusinesses, and other organizations. Study basic agricultural sciences, agricultural business operations, pest control, adult education methods, public relations, applicable state laws and regulations, and communication skills.

name: Agricultural Communication/Journalism
shortdescription: Learn how to create news, education and other content for agricultural audiences.
description: Apply journalistic, communication, and broadcasting principles to the development, production, and transmittal of agricultural information. Study basic journalism, broadcasting, film/video, and communication techniques; the production of technically specialized information products for agricultural audiences; and the principles of agricultural sciences and business operations needed to develop and effectively communicate about agricultural subjects.

name: Animal Sciences
shortdescription: Learn how to breed and produce agricultural animals.
description: Learn scientific principles for the breeding and husbandry of agricultural animals, and the production, processing, and distribution of agricultural animal products. Study the animal sciences, animal husbandry and production, and agricultural and food products processing.

name: Agricultural Animal Breeding
shortdescription: Use genetics, animal science, and technology to improve animal breeds.
description: Apply genetics and genetic engineering to the improvement of agricultural animal health, the development of new animal breeds, and the selective improvement of agricultural animal populations. Study genetics, genetic engineering, population genetics, animal health, animal husbandry, and biotechnology.

name: Animal Health
shortdescription: Learn how to improve agricultural animals' health in food production.
description: Apply biological and chemical principles to the study, prevention, and control of diseases in agricultural animal populations. Study environmental science, pharmacology, animal population studies, genetics, animal physiology and diet, disease prevention, treatment methodologies, and laboratory and testing procedures.

name: Animal Nutrition
shortdescription: Learn how to improve agricultural animals' diet to improve health and production.
description: Learn the biology and chemistry of proteins, fats, carbohydrates, water, vitamins, and feed additives as related to animal health and the production of improved animal products. Study nutrition science, animal health and physiology, biochemistry, cellular and molecular biology, animal husbandry, and food science.

name: Dairy Science
shortdescription: Use biology and chemistry in dairy production, protecting animal and human health.
description: Apply biological and chemical principles to the production and management of dairy animals and the production and handling of dairy products. Study animal sciences, nutrition sciences, food science and technology, biochemistry, and related aspects of human and animal health and safety.

name: Livestock Management
shortdescription: Use biology and chemistry in animal production, protecting animal and human health.
description: Apply biological and chemical principles to the production and management of livestock animals and the production and handling of meat and other products. Study animal sciences, range science, nutrition sciences, food science and technology, biochemistry, and related aspects of human and animal health and safety.

name: Poultry Science
shortdescription: Use biology and chemistry in poultry production, protecting bird and human health.
description: Apply biological and chemical principles to the production and management of poultry animals and the production and handling of poultry products. Study avian sciences, nutrition sciences, food science and technology, biochemistry, hatchery design, and related aspects of human and animal health and safety.

name: Food Science
shortdescription: Learn how to create and store agricultural products for human consumption.
description: Apply biological, chemical, and physical principles to the study of converting raw agricultural products into processed forms suitable for direct human consumption, and their storage. Study agricultural sciences, human physiology and nutrition, food chemistry, agricultural products processing, food additives, food preparation and packaging, food storage and shipment, and related aspects of human health and safety including toxicology and pathology.

name: Food Technology and Processing
shortdescription: Learn how to develop, manufacture, store and ship food products.
description: Apply chemical, physical, and engineering principles to the development and implementation of manufacturing, packaging, storage, and distribution technologies and processes for food products. Study food engineering, food preservation and handling, food preparation, food packaging and display, food storage and shipment, and related equipment and facilities design, operation, and maintenance.

name: Brewing Science
shortdescription: Learn how to brew beer and operate a brewing business.
description: Study the business, science, and technology of beer brewing operations. Includes instruction in biology, biochemistry, brewing, entrepreneurship, fermentation, malting, marketing, microbiology, quality control, and sanitation.

name: Fermentation Science
shortdescription: Learn how to create fermented food products and operate a related business.
description: Study the business, science, and technology of fermented food production. Includes instruction in biology, biochemistry, brewing, entrepreneurship, fermentation, marketing, microbiology, quality control, and sanitation.

name: Plant Sciences
shortdescription: Learn how to breed and grow plants and process their products.
description: Learn scientific principles for breeding, cultivation, and production of agricultural plants, and the production, processing, and distribution of agricultural plant products. Study plant sciences, crop cultivation and production, and agricultural and food products processing.

name: Agronomy and Crop Science
shortdescription: Learn how crops and soils affect one another to improve the health of both.
description: Learn the chemical, physical, and biological relationships of crops and the soils nurturing them. Study the growth and behavior of agricultural crops, the development of new plant varieties, and the scientific management of soils and nutrients for maximum plant nutrition, health, and productivity.

name: Horticultural Science
shortdescription: Learn how to grow and manage garden, landscape and nursery plants.
description: Learn the scientific principles related to the cultivation of garden and ornamental plants, including fruits, vegetables, flowers, and landscape and nursery crops. Study specific types of plants, such as citrus; breeding horticultural varieties; physiology of horticultural species; and the scientific management of horticultural plant development and production through the life cycle.

name: Agricultural and Horticultural Plant Breeding
shortdescription: Learn how to breed plants to improve their health and productivity.
description: Apply genetics and genetic engineering to the improvement of agricultural plant health, the development of new plant varieties, and the selective improvement of agricultural plant populations. Study genetics, genetic engineering, population genetics, agronomy, plant protection, and biotechnology.

name: Plant Protection and Integrated Pest Management
shortdescription: Learn how to reduce or control animals, insects, and other pests to protect plants.
description: Apply scientific principles to the control of animal, insect and weed infestation of domesticated plant populations and other settings, including agricultural crops; the prevention/reduction of attendant economic loss; and the control of environmental pollution and degradation related to pest infestation and pest control measures. Study entomology, applicable animal sciences, plant pathology and physiology, weed science, crop science, and environmental toxicology.

name: Range Science and Management
shortdescription: Study grass, range and arid lands to improve their productivity and environmental balance.
description: Scientific study of rangelands, arid regions, grasslands, and other areas of low productivity, as well as the principles of managing such resources for maximum benefit and environmental balance. Learn about livestock management, wildlife biology, plant sciences, ecology, soil science, and hydrology.

name: Soil Science and Agronomy
shortdescription: Learn how to improve soils and their relationship to crop production.
description: Study the scientific classification of soils, soil properties, and their relationship to agricultural crops. Learn about soil chemistry, soil physics, soil biology, soil fertility, morphogenesis, mineralogy, hydrology, agronomy, and soil conservation and management.

name: Soil Chemistry and Physics
shortdescription: Learn how soils and water interact to improve their quality and productivity.
description: Apply chemical and physical principles to research and analysis concerning the nature and properties of soils and the conservation and management of soils. Study soil and fluid mechanics, mineralogy, sedimentology, thermodynamics, geomorphology, environmental systems, analytical methods, and organic and inorganic chemistry.

name: Soil Microbiology
shortdescription: Learn how soil microorganisms impact soil-animal and soil-plant relationships.
description: Apply microbiological theory and methods to the study of the organismic properties of soils, soil-plant and soil-animal interactions, and the biological components and effects of soil management strategies. Learn about microbiology and related biological sciences, applicable animal and plant sciences, soil chemistry and physics as related to biological characteristics, and environmental science.

name: Natural Resources/Conservation
shortdescription: Learn how the climate, air, soil, water and living things interact to improve their conservation.
description: A general study of the natural environment and its conservation, use, and improvement. Includes instruction in subjects such as climate, air, soil, water, land, fish and wildlife, and plant resources; in the basic principles of environmental science and natural resources management; and the recreational and economic uses of renewable and nonrenewable natural resources.

name: Environmental Studies
shortdescription: Study environmental issues using a combination of science, economics and humanistic approaches.
description: Learn about environment-related issues using scientific, social scientific, or humanistic approaches or a combination. Study the basic principles of ecology and environmental science and related subjects such as policy, politics, law, economics, social aspects, planning, pollution control, natural resources, and the interactions of human beings and nature.

name: Environmental Science
shortdescription: Learn how to solve environmental problems in a variety of scientific ways.
description: A program that focuses on the application of biological, chemical, and physical principles to the study of the physical environment and the solution of environmental problems, including subjects such as abating or controlling environmental pollution and degradation; the interaction between human society and the natural environment; and natural resources management. Includes instruction in biology, chemistry, physics, geosciences, climatology, statistics, and mathematical modeling.

name: Natural Resources Management and Policy
shortdescription: Learn how to create and manage programs that protect natural resources.
description: A program that prepares individuals to plan, develop, manage, and evaluate programs to protect and regulate natural habitats and renewable natural resources. Includes instruction in the principles of wildlife and conservation biology, environmental science, animal population surveying, natural resource economics, management techniques for various habitats, applicable law and policy, administrative and communications skills, and public relations.

name: Natural Resource Economics
shortdescription: Learn how to analyze environmental problems using economics.
description: Apply economic concepts and methods to the analysis of air and water pollution, land use planning, waste disposal, invasive species and pest control, conservation policies, and related environmental problems. Study cost-benefit analysis, environmental impact assessment, evaluation and assessment of alternative resource management strategies, policy evaluation and monitoring, and descriptive and analytic tools for studying how environmental developments affect the economic system.

name: Water, Wetlands, and Marine Resources Management
shortdescription: Learn how to conserve fresh and saltwater environments.
description: Apply principles of marine/aquatic biology, oceanography, natural resource economics, and natural resources management to the development, conservation, and management of freshwater and saltwater environments. Study wetlands, riverine, lacustrian, coastal, and oceanic water resources; water conservation and use; flood control; pollution control; water supply logistics; wastewater management; aquatic and marine ecology; aquatic and marine life conservation; and the economic and recreational uses of water resources.

name: Land Use Planning and Management/Development
shortdescription: Learn how to maximize the benefits of public and private land through planning and analysis.
description: Learn how public and/or private land and associated resources can be preserved, developed, and used for maximum social, economic, and environmental benefit. Study natural resources management, natural resource economics, public policy, regional and land use planning, environmental impact assessment, applicable law and regulations, government and politics, principles of business and real estate land use, statistical and analytical tools, computer applications, mapping and report preparation, site analysis, cost analysis, and communications skills.

name: Natural Resource Recreation and Tourism
shortdescription: Learn how to balance tourism, local culture and the environment to benefit everyone.
description: Learn how to plan, develop, and manage tourism in a natural resource setting, with an emphasis on applying environmentally sound, culturally sensitive, and economically sustainable principles. Study environmental studies; natural resource management and interpretation; tourism planning, management, and policies; public land use management and policies; communications; marketing; and public relations.

name: Natural Resources Law Enforcement and Protective Services
shortdescription: Learn how to educate about and enforce laws to protect human life, natural resources, and wildlife.
description: Learn about natural resource and environmental protection regulations and laws; and how to perform emergency duties to protect human life, property and natural resources, including fire prevention and control measures, and emergency and rescue procedures. Study natural and physical sciences, natural resource management, outdoor field skills, firearms and outdoor equipment and vehicle operation, evidence collection and environmental sampling and monitoring, natural resource legislation, environmental compliance techniques, patrol procedures, investigation and report writing, interpersonal skills and crisis intervention, community liaison, public safety, public education, and public relations.

name: Fishing and Fisheries Sciences and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to conserve wild fish and shellfish for recreation and sale.
description: Learn the scientific study of the husbandry and production of non-domesticated fish and shellfish populations for recreational and commercial purposes and the management of fishing and marine/aquatic product processing to ensure adequate conservation and efficient utilization.Study the principles of marine/aquatic biology, freshwater and saltwater ecosystems, water resources, fishing production operations and management, fishing policy and regulation, and the management of recreational and commercial fishing activities.

name: Forestry
shortdescription: Learn how to manage forests in sustainable ways.
description: Learn how to manage and develop forest areas for economic, recreational, and ecological purposes. Study forest-related sciences, mapping, statistics, harvesting and production technology, natural resources management and economics, wildlife sciences, administration, and public relations.

name: Forest Sciences and Biology
shortdescription: Study how environmental factors like soil and water impact forest growth.
description: Apply one or more forest-related sciences to the study of environmental factors affecting forests and the growth and management of forest resources. Study forest biology, forest hydrology, forest mensuration, silviculture, forest soils, water resources, environmental science, forest resources management, and wood science.

name: Forest Management/Forest Resources Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage forest lands using the science of forestry and conservation.
description: Apply principles of forestry and natural resources management to the administration of forest lands and related resources. Study silviculture, forest mensuration, forest protection, inventorying, biometrics, geographic information systems, remote sensing, photogrammetry, forest policy and economics, forest land use planning, fire protection and management, and related administrative skills.

name: Urban Forestry
shortdescription: Learn how to manage and protect trees in cities and densely populated areas.
description: Apply the principles of forestry and related sciences to the development, care, and maintenance of individual trees and forested areas within or close to areas of dense human habitation. Study urban environments; effects of pollution on tree species; environmental design and landscaping; urban pest infestation; urban forest management; and applicable policies and regulations.

name: Wood Science and Wood Products/Pulp and Paper Technology
shortdescription: Study how wood products are developed.
description: Apply chemical, physical, and engineering principles to the analysis of the properties and behavior of wood and wood products and the development of processes for converting wood into paper and other products. Study wood classification and testing, product development, manufacturing and processing technologies, and the design and development of related equipment and systems.

name: Forest Resources Production and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage forests to produce, harvest and process wood.
description: Apply forestry principles to the production, harvesting, and processing of forest resources. Study forest production and utilization, industrial forestry, agroforestry, transplantation, timber harvesting, selection and identification of trees, processing technologies and systems, equipment operations and maintenance, and related management skills.

name: Forest Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Help manage forests in the field, including harvesting, measuring and identifying trees.
description: Assist foresters in the management and production of forest resources. Includes instruction in woods and field skills, tree identification, timber measurement, logging and timber harvesting, forest propagation and regeneration, forest fire-fighting, resource management, equipment operation and maintenance, record-keeping, sales and purchasing operations, and personnel supervision.

name: Wildlife, Fish and Wildlands Science and Management
shortdescription: Learn how to manage wildlife areas for the public.
description: Conserve and manage wilderness areas and the flora, marine and aquatic life therein, and manage wildlife reservations and zoological/aquarium facilities for recreational, commercial, and ecological purposes. Study wildlife biology, marine/aquatic biology, environmental science, freshwater and saltwater ecosystems, natural resources management and policy, outdoor recreation and parks management, the design and operation of natural and artificial wildlife habitats, applicable law and regulations, and related administrative and communications skills.

name: Architecture
shortdescription: Learn the foundation subjects for becoming an architect.
description: Prepare for the independent professional practice of architecture and to conduct research in various aspects of the field. Study architectural design, history, and theory; building structures and environmental systems; project and site planning; construction; professional responsibilities and standards; and related cultural, social, economic, and environmental issues.

name: City/Urban, Community and Regional Planning
shortdescription: Learn how to plan and improve city communities through building, parks and transportation.
description: Apply principles of planning, analysis, and architecture to the development and improvement of urban areas and surrounding regions, and to function as professional planners. Study principles of architecture; master plan development; service, communications, and transportation systems design; community and commercial development; zoning; land use planning; applied economics; policy analysis; applicable laws and regulations; and professional responsibilities and managerial duties.

name: Environmental Design/Architecture
shortdescription: Design places to live, work and play.
description: Design public and private spaces, indoor and outdoor, for leisure, recreational, commercial, and living purposes, and for professional practice as environmental designers and architects. Study the design and planning of public and private open spaces and their relationship to buildings and other aspects of the built environment; facilities management; related aspects of interior design and architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning; and professional responsibilities and standards.

name: Interior Architecture
shortdescription: Learn how how to combine architecture with interior design.
description: Apply architectural principles in the design of structural interiors for living, recreational, and business purposes and to function as professional interior architects. Study architecture, structural systems design, heating and cooling systems, occupational and safety standards, interior design, specific end-use applications, and professional responsibilities and standards.

name: Landscape Architecture
shortdescription: Design outdoor spaces, considering the science of geology and horticulture.
description: Prepare for the independent professional practice of landscape architecture and research in various aspects of the field. Study geology and hydrology; soils, groundcovers, and horticultural elements; project and site planning; landscape design, history, and theory; environmental design; applicable law and regulations; and professional responsibilities and standards.

name: Architectural History and Criticism
shortdescription: Learn how our society was built and evaluate present-day impacts.
description: Learn about aesthetic, technical, and social development of the built environment and the architectural profession from earliest times to the present. Study principles of architecture and related fields; art history; historiography of architecture; architectural theory and criticism; related aspects of the history of technology and social and economic history; and various period, cultural, and stylistic specializations.

name: Architectural Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Help plan, design and draft architecture projects.
description: Assist architects in developing plans and related documentation and in performing architectural office services. Study architectural drafting, computer-assisted drafting and design, construction methods and materials, environmental systems, building codes and standards, structural principles, cost estimation, planning documentation, visual communication skills, display production, and architectural office management.

name: Architectural and Building Sciences/Technology
shortdescription: Use building technology to reduce negative environmental impacts and increase conservation.
description: Apply advanced technology to building design and construction, retrofitting existing buildings, and efficient operation of buildings, including lighting and daylight design, acoustics, solar design, building conservation, and energy-conscious design. Study architecture, building technology, civil and structural engineering, mechanical engineering, environmental control systems, sustainability, and computer tools and applications.

name: Real Estate Development
shortdescription: Learn how to design and develop housing, commercial and industrial sites.
description: Create and redevelop housing, offices, retail centers, and industrial sites. Study architectural design and construction, historic preservation, landscape architecture, urban planning and design, business, real estate and land use law, public policy, and engineering.

name: African Studies
shortdescription: Study African history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of the African Continent, usually with an emphasis on Africa south of the Sahara, and including the African diasporas overseas.

name: American/United States Studies/Civilization
shortdescription: Study U.S. and pre-U.S. history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the United States and its Pre-Columbian and colonial predecessors, and including the flow of immigrants from other societies.

name: Asian Studies/Civilization
shortdescription: Study Asian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of the Asian Continent, including the study of the Asian diasporas overseas.

name: East Asian Studies
shortdescription: Study East Asian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of East Asia, defined as including China, Korea, Japan, Mongolia, Taiwan, Tibet, related borderlands and island groups, and including the study of the East Asian diasporas overseas.

name: Russian, Central European, East European and Eurasian Studies
shortdescription: Study Russian and formerly Communist countries' history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the region encompassing Russia, Central Europe, Eastern Europe, and Eurasia, including the Balkan, Baltic, Caucasus, and Central Asian states that were republics of the former Soviet Union.

name: European Studies/Civilization
shortdescription: Study European history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of the European Continent, including the study of European migration patterns and colonial empires.

name: Latin American Studies
shortdescription: Study Latin American history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the Hispanic peoples of the North and South American Continents outside Canada and the United States, including the study of the Pre-Columbian period and the flow of immigrants from other societies.

name: Near and Middle Eastern Studies
shortdescription: Study North African, Asia and Middle Eastern history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of North Africa, Southwestern Asia, Asia Minor, and the Arabian Peninsula, related borderlands and island groups, and including emigrant and immigrant groups.

name: Pacific Area/Pacific Rim Studies
shortdescription: Study Australasia and Pacific area history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of Australasia and the Pacific Ocean, related island groups and bordering coastal regions, and including pre- and post-colonial migration patterns.

name: Russian Studies
shortdescription: Study Russian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of the Russian Federation and its Soviet, Czarist, and medieval predecessors and related borderlands.

name: Scandinavian Studies
shortdescription: Study Scandanavian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of Scandinavia, defined as Northern Europe including Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, related island groups (including Greenland), and borderlands.

name: South Asian Studies
shortdescription: Study South Asian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of South Asia, defined as including Afghanistan, India, the Maldives, Myanmar (Burma), Pakistan, and Sri Lanka and related borderlands and island groups; and including the study of migration patterns and overseas diasporas.

name: Southeast Asian Studies
shortdescription: Study Southeast Asian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of Southeast Asia, defined as including Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, The Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam; related borderlands and island groups; and including the study of migration patterns and overseas diasporas.

name: Western European Studies
shortdescription: Study Western European history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of historical Western Europe, defined as including Britain, Ireland, France, the Low Countries, the Iberian Peninsula, Italy, the Western Mediterranean, and related island groups and borderlands.

name: Canadian Studies
shortdescription: Study Canadian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of Canada and its Pre-Columbian, colonial, and pre-federation predecessors, including immigrant flows and related borderlands and island groups.

name: Balkans Studies
shortdescription: Study Balkan Peninsula history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples inhabiting the Balkan Peninsula and associated island groups and borderlands, Southern Slavic and non-Slavic, during the medieval, Ottoman, and modern periods.

name: Baltic Studies
shortdescription: Study Baltic Sea coastland history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples inhabiting the coastlands of the Baltic Sea, including Baltic, Germanic, Scandinavian, and Slavic populations, related borderlands and island groups, and problems of cultural survival and assimilation.

name: Slavic Studies
shortdescription: Study Slavic history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the Slavic peoples inhabiting Europe, Asia, and in immigrant groups elsewhere, including the study of the emergence and migration patterns of Slavic culture, languages, and populations.

name: Caribbean Studies
shortdescription: Study Caribbean history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples inhabiting the major islands and archipelagoes of the Caribbean Sea and related coastal borderlands, including immigration patterns and Pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern societies.

name: Ural-Altaic and Central Asian Studies
shortdescription: Study Inner/Central Asian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples and countries of Inner/Central Asia, including the Turkic and Mongolian inhabitants of the Caspian, Amur, Tien Shan, Baikal, Gobi, Siberian, and Manchurian areas and the historical Silk Road, in terms of their past and present development.

name: Commonwealth Studies
shortdescription: Study Commonwealth and related British history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples and countries comprising components of the historical British Empire and modern British Commonwealth, including migration patterns, shared sociocultural and political features and problems, and contemporary relations.

name: Regional Studies (US, Canadian, Foreign)
shortdescription: Study North American regional history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the defined geographic subregions and subcultures within modern and historical countries and societies. Includes such topics as Acadian Studies, French Canadian and Quebec Studies, Southern (U.S.) Studies, Appalachian (U.S.) Studies, New England Studies, Southwestern Studies, Northern Studies, and others.

name: Chinese Studies
shortdescription: Study Chinese history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the peoples of present-day China and its historical predecessors, related borderlands and island groups, and the overseas Chinese diaspora.

name: French Studies
shortdescription: Study French history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of France, other Francophone countries inside and outside Europe, and the French colonial experience and the associated French minorities around the world.

name: German Studies
shortdescription: Study German history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of Germany, the neighboring countries of Austria and Switzerland, the German minorities in neighboring European countries, and the historical areas of German influence across Europe and overseas.

name: Italian Studies
shortdescription: Study Italian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of modern Italy and its predecessors on the Italian Peninsula, including the overseas migrations of Italian peoples.

name: Japanese Studies
shortdescription: Study Japanese history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the peoples of Japan, and related island groups and coastal neighbors.

name: Korean Studies
shortdescription: Study Korean history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the peoples of Korea, including related island groups and borderlands.

name: Polish Studies
shortdescription: Study Polish history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of Poland and the current and historical inhabitants of the Polish lands, including borderlands, from earliest times to the present.

name: Spanish and Iberian Studies
shortdescription: Study Iberian Peninsula history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the peoples of the Iberian Peninsula and related island groups and border regions from earliest times to the present, with particular emphasis on the development of Spain and Portugal but including other historical and current cultures.

name: Tibetan Studies
shortdescription: Study Tibetan history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of Tibet and its borderlands, with emphasis on both pre-modern and modern Tibet and associated religious and exile movements.

name: Ukraine Studies
shortdescription: Study Ukrainian history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the Ukraine and its inhabitants, and related border regions, from earliest times to the present.

name: Irish Studies
shortdescription: Study Irish history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of Ireland and the Irish Diaspora, from the early Christian period to the present.

name: Latin American and Caribbean Studies
shortdescription: Study Latin American and Caribbean history, society, politics, culture, and economics.
description: Learn about the history, society, politics, culture, and economics of the peoples and countries of the Latin American and Caribbean region.

name: Ethnic Studies
shortdescription: Study North American racial and ethnic groups through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of North American racial and ethnic groups, including African Americans, American Indians/Native Americans, Hispanic Americans, and Asian Americans.

name: African-American/Black Studies
shortdescription: Study African-Americans and people of color through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of the North American peoples descended from the African diaspora; focusing on the United States, Canada, and the Caribbean, but also including reference to Latin American elements of the diaspora.

name: American Indian/Native American Studies
shortdescription: Study Native Americans through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the American Indian, Aleut, Inuit, Hawaiian and other native peoples of the Americas from earliest times until the present, with particular emphasis on U.S. and Canadian populations and their problems but including reference to Caribbean and Latin American native peoples.

name: Hispanic-American, Puerto Rican, and Mexican-American/Chicano Studies
shortdescription: Study Hispanic Americans through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of one or more of the Hispanic American immigrant populations within the U.S. and Canada, including Mexican-American Studies, Cuban American Studies, Puerto Rican Studies, and others.

name: Asian-American Studies
shortdescription: Study Asian-Americans through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of Asian population groups who have immigrated to the United States and Canada, or sought refugee asylum, from the colonial period to the present, and including Chinese-Americans, Japanese-Americans, Korean-Americans, Vietnamese-Americans, Cambodian-Americans, and others.

name: Womens Studies
shortdescription: Study women through perspectives like history, politics, literature and art.
description: Learn about the history, sociology, politics, culture, and economics of women, and the development of modern feminism in relation to the roles played by women in different periods and locations in North America and the world. Programs may focus on literature, philosophy, and the arts as much as on social studies and policy.

name: Gay/Lesbian Studies
shortdescription: Study gays and lesbians through perspectives like history, politics and culture.
description: Learn about homosexuality in history, society, politics, and cultural life; usually with an emphasis on the modern emergence of gays and lesbians as a sociocultural minority movement, the identification of social, literary, and artistic themes and the definition of, and public policy and legal issues surrounding, the gay and lesbian community.

name: Folklore Studies
shortdescription: Study creative expression in everyday life through literature, art, and culture.
description: Learn about creativity and aesthetic expression in everyday life, as expressed in narrative, literature, performing arts, culture, work, family and community.

name: Disability Studies
shortdescription: Study history, culture, economics and other dynamics of disability.
description: Focus on the nature, meaning, and consequences of what it is to be defined as disabled and explores the historical, cultural, economic, physiological, and socio-political dynamics of disability. Study disability rights, legal issues, and public policy; literature, philosophy, and the arts; and/or research in the social sciences, education, and health sciences addressing social and experiential aspects of disability.

name: Deaf Studies
shortdescription: Study history, culture, economics and other dynamics of deaf people.
description: A program that focuses on the sociological, historical and linguistic aspects of the deaf and hearing impaired, and that prepares individuals to work with the deaf and hearing impaired. Study American Sign Language, deaf studies, American deaf culture, structure of American Sign Language, history of the American deaf community, and civil rights of deaf people.

name: Communication, General
shortdescription: Study applications of media and communication within society.
description: Learn about the comprehensive study of communication, and that spans the study of mass communication/media studies, old and new media technologies, social and political applications, and speech communication and rhetoric. Study interpersonal, group, organizational, and intercultural communication; theories of communication; critical thinking, argumentation, and persuasion; written communication; printed, electronic, and digital media; rhetorical tradition and criticism; media, society, and culture; consequences and effects of mass media; media social science and criticism; and quantitative and qualitative methods of inquiry.

name: Speech Communication and Rhetoric
shortdescription: Learn about different applications of speech and communication in different contexts.
description: Study the scientific, humanistic, and critical study of human communication in a variety of formats, media, and contexts. Learn about the theory and practice of interpersonal, group, organizational, professional, and intercultural communication; speaking and listening; verbal and nonverbal interaction; rhetorical theory and criticism; performance studies; argumentation and persuasion; technologically mediated communication; popular culture; and various contextual applications.

name: Mass Communication/Media Studies
shortdescription: Learn to interpret the media's influence on culture, history,  human behavior.
description: Study the analysis and criticism of media institutions and media texts, how people experience and understand media content, and the roles of media in producing and transforming culture. Learn about communications regulation, law, and policy; media history; media aesthetics, interpretation, and criticism; the social and cultural effects of mass media; cultural studies; the economics of media industries; visual and media literacy; and the psychology and behavioral aspects of media messages, interpretation, and utilization.

name: Journalism
shortdescription: Learn how to collect, edit, and write about news for the public.
description: Study the theory and practice of gathering, processing, and delivering news and that prepares individuals to be professional print journalists, news editors, and news managers. Learn about news writing and editing; reporting; photojournalism; layout and graphic design; journalism law and policy; professional standards and ethics; research methods; and journalism history and criticism.

name: Broadcast Journalism
shortdescription: Learn ways to deliver news through different forms of broadcast media.
description: Study the methods and techniques for reporting, producing, and delivering news and news programs via radio, television, and video/film media; and that prepares individuals to be professional broadcast journalists, editors, producers, directors, and managers. Learn the principles of broadcast technology; broadcast reporting; on- and off-camera and microphone procedures and techniques; program, sound, and video/film editing; program design and production; media law and policy; and professional standards and ethics.

name: Radio and Television
shortdescription: Learn strategies to distribute information and work within radio and television organizations.
description: Study the theories, methods, and techniques used to plan, produce, and distribute audio and video programs and messages, and that prepares individuals to function as staff, producers, directors, and managers of radio and television shows and media organizations. Learn about media aesthetics; planning, scheduling, and production; writing and editing; performing and directing; personnel and facilities management; marketing and distribution; media regulations, law, and policy; and principles of broadcast technology.

name: Digital Communication and Media/Multimedia
shortdescription: ****************Study how the media functions using technology
description: Learn development, use, critical evaluation, and regulation of new electronic communication technologies using computer applications; and that prepares individuals to function as developers and managers of digital communications media. Study computer and telecommunications technologies and processes; design and development of digital communications; marketing and distribution; digital communications regulation, law, and policy; the study of human interaction with, and use of, digital media; and emerging trends and issues.

name: Public Relations, Advertising, and Applied Communication
shortdescription: Learn how to use advertising and marketing strategies to relay a message effectively.
description: Study organizational communication, public relations, and advertising; and that prepares individuals to function in a wide range of public and private sector positions requiring the skills of persuasive communication. Learn about communications, public relations, and advertising theory; principles and techniques of persuasion; message/image design; marketing strategy; professional writing; public speaking and multi-media presentation skills; digital communications; and applied research.

name: Organizational Communication, General
shortdescription: Learn how people work together and communicate in an organization.
description: Learn about general communication processes and dynamics within organizations. Study the development and maintenance of interpersonal group relations within organizations; decision-making and conflict management; the use of symbols to create and maintain organizational images, missions, and values; power and politics within organizations; human interaction with computer technology; and how communications socializes and supports employees and team members.

name: Public Relations/Image Management
shortdescription: Learn to help manage the reputation of an organization through the media and public affairs.
description: Study theories and methods for managing the media image of a business, organization, or individual and the communication process with stakeholders, constituencies, audiences, and the general public; and that prepares individuals to function as public relations assistants, technicians, and managers. Learn about public relations theory; related principles of advertising, marketing, and journalism; message/image design; image management; special event management; media relations; community relations; public affairs; and internal communications.

name: Advertising
shortdescription: Learn how to create and evaluate commercial messages to best sell a product or idea.
description: Study the creation, execution, transmission, and evaluation of commercial messages in various media intended to promote and sell products, services, and brands; and that prepares individuals to function as advertising assistants, technicians, and managers. Learn about advertising theory, marketing strategy, advertising design and production methods, campaign methods and techniques, media management, related principles of business management, and applicable technical and equipment skills.

name: Political Communication
shortdescription: Learn about managing media communications in a political environment
description: Study human and media communication in the political process and that prepares individuals to function as members of political and public affairs organizations, political campaign staffs, and related government and media entities. Learn about media effects, political speaking and debating, political advertising and marketing, image management, political journalism, opinion polling, and aspects of print and broadcast media related to the production and distribution of media messages in political settings.

name: Health Communication
shortdescription: Learn how to advocate for the public through health-related messages and promotions.
description: Study how people, individually and collectively, understand and accommodate to health and illness and the role of communication and media in shaping professional health care messages and public acceptance of these messages. Learn about the development and use of health-related and care-related messages and media; the goals and strategies of health care promotion; relationships, roles, situations, and social structures in the context of health maintenance and promotion; and applications to disease prevention, health advocacy, and communications concerning treatments.

name: Sports Communication
shortdescription: Learn to use different forms of media to communicate about sports.
description: Study the methods and techniques for communicating about sports in a variety of formats, media, and contexts; and that prepares individuals to be sports reporters and writers, photojournalists, radio and television announcers, producers and directors, recreational sports promoters, and public relations specialists. Learn sports writing, photography, broadcast journalism, sports production, game rules, media and public relations, and sports promotion.

name: International and Intercultural Communication
shortdescription: Learn about communicating effectively between cultures and during international relations.
description: Apply the specialized knowledge and skills needed for effective communication in the international community and among people of different cultures; and that prepares individuals to function at the national and international levels as journalists, public relations specialists, travel industry representatives, intercultural trainers, and/or foreign service officers. Study journalism, communications, intercultural and international relations, marketing and public relations, and global communications policy.

name: Technical and Scientific Communication
shortdescription: Learn how to use the media to communicate about scientific topics.
description: Study the communication of technical and scientific knowledge to a variety of audiences through print, video, and digital media; and that prepares individuals to function as technical writers and editors, documentation developers, web designers, and usability specialists. Learn about scientific and technical writing and editing, graphic and information design, web design, audience analysis, document usability and field testing, publications management, and applications to specific technical fields.

name: Publishing
shortdescription: Learn how to publish and distribute textual creations.
description: Study the process of managing the creation, publication, and distribution of print and electronic books and other text products and prepares individuals to manage the editorial, technical, and business aspects of publishing operations. Learn about product planning and design, editing, author relations, business and copyright law, publishing industry operations, contracting and purchasing, product marketing, electronic publishing and commerce, history of publishing, and professional standards and ethics.

name: Communications Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn skills to function within a communication organization.
description: Study to function as workers and managers within communications industries. Learn about business economics; basic management; principles of interpersonal and mediated communications; radio, television, and digital media production; and related aspects of technology and communications systems.

name: Photographic and Film/Video Technology/Technician and Assistant
shortdescription: Learn to use production equipment for creating photographs, films, and videos.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to the operation and maintenance of camera and lighting equipment and the production of finished still, video, and film products under the supervision of photographers, directors, and editors. Learn about equipment setup and maintenance; lighting; power supplies; studio and film set tasks such as camera operator, grip, and best boy; plate and negative handling and development; laboratory procedures; and digital software applications.

name: Radio and Television Broadcasting Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn to use production equipment for creating radio and television broadcasts.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to the production of radio and television programs, and related operations, under the supervision of broadcast and studio managers, directors, editors, and producers. Learn about sound, lighting, and camera operation and maintenance; power and feed control; studio operations; production preparation; broadcast engineering; related computer applications; and specialized applications such as news, entertainment, live talk, sports, commercials, and taping.

name: Recording Arts Technology/Technician
shortdescription: Learn how to produce and use sound effects to aid in media projects.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to the production of sound recordings as finished products or as components of film/video, broadcast, live, or mixed media productions. Learn about sound equipment operation and maintenance; music, dialogue, and sound effects recording; sound track editing; dubbing and mixing; sound engineering; tape, disk, and CD production; digital recording and transmission; amplification and modulation; and working with producers, editors, directors, artists, and production managers.

name: Graphic Communications, General
shortdescription: Learn to create and distribute graphics in different media forms.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills in the manufacture and distribution or transmission of graphic communications products. Learn about the prepress, press, and postpress phases of production operations and processes such as offset lithography, flexography, gravure, letterpress, screen printing, foil stamping, digital imaging, and other reproduction methods.

name: Printing Management
shortdescription: Learn to manage and produce printing projects.
description: Study how to apply technical and managerial knowledge and skills to the processes and procedures of managing printing operations from initial design through finished product distribution. Learn about the principles of graphic communications design and production; quality control; printing operations management; computerization; printing plant management; business finance and marketing; logistics and distribution; personnel supervision and leadership; and professional standards in the graphic communications industry.

name: Prepress/Desktop Publishing and Digital Imaging Design
shortdescription: Learn how to prepare graphic and/or textual products for production/release.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to the layout, design and typographic arrangement of printed and/or electronic graphic and textual products. Learn about printing and lithographic equipment and operations, computer hardware and software, digital imaging, print preparation, page layout and design, desktop publishing, and applicable principles of graphic design and web page design.

name: Animation, Interactive Technology, Video Graphics and Special Effects
shortdescription: Learn how to create sound and visual effects.
description: Study how to use computer applications and related visual and sound imaging techniques to manipulate images and information originating as film, video, still photographs, digital copy, soundtracks, and physical objects in order to communicate messages simulating real-world content. Learn about specialized camerawork and equipment operation and maintenance, image capture, computer programming, dubbing, CAD applications, and applications to specific commercial, industrial, and entertainment needs.

name: Graphic and Printing Equipment Operator, General Production
shortdescription: Learn to utilize special equipment for the production of various forms of media.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to plan, prepare, and execute a variety of commercial and industrial graphic communications jobs. Learn about the operation and maintenance of mechanical, electronic, and digital graphic, printing, and finishing equipment; and related processes.

name: Platemaker/Imager
shortdescription: Learn how to prepare graphic and textual products for production/release.
description: Learn to apply technical knowledge and skills to prepare film, digital data, and surfaces to reproduce printed or graphic images. Study platemaking, stripping, camerawork, imposition, digital imaging, computer direct-to-plate and direct-to-press, and related processes.

name: Printing Press Operator
shortdescription: Learn how to use a printing press.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to set up, operate, and maintain printing presses.

name: Computer Typography and Composition Equipment Operator
shortdescription: Learn how to design the layout for pages and textual creations.
description: Study how to apply technical knowledge and skills to design and execute page formats, layouts and text composition, and to make typographical selections using computer graphics and other computer-assisted design programs.

name: Computer and Information Sciences
shortdescription: Study a broad range of computer and information sciences.
description: General study of computing, computer science, and information science and systems.

name: Artificial Intelligence
shortdescription: Learn how to create simulations of human intelligence in computers and software.
description: Study the symbolic inference, representation, and simulation by computers and software of human learning and reasoning processes and capabilities, and the computer modeling of human motor control and motion. Learn skills in computing theory, cybernetics, human factors, natural language processing, and applicable aspects of engineering, technology, and specific end-use applications.

name: Information Technology
shortdescription: Learn how to design data and communications information systems.
description: Learn about the design of technological information systems, including computing systems, as solutions to business and research data and communications support needs. Study principles of computer hardware and software components, algorithms, databases, telecommunications, user tactics, application testing, and human interface design.

name: Informatics
shortdescription: Learn about the relationship between artificial and natural systems using computer technology.
description: Study computer systems from a user-centered perspective and the structure, behavior and interactions of natural and artificial systems that store, process and communicate information. Learn information sciences, human computer interaction, information system analysis and design, telecommunications structure and information architecture and management.

name: Computer Programming/Programmer
shortdescription: Learn how to create computer programs and fix problems through code.
description: Study the general writing and implementation of generic and customized programs to drive operating systems and that generally prepares individuals to apply the methods and procedures of software design and programming to software installation and maintenance.
